definitions.definition: Beautiful , of a pleasing appearance, with a pure and fresh quality.
examples: Monday's child is fair of face.
There was once a knight who wooed a fair young maid.

definitions.definition: Unblemished (figuratively or literally); clean and pure ; innocent.
examples: After scratching out and replacing various words in the manuscript, he scribed a fair copy to send to the publisher.

definitions.definition: Light in color, pale , particularly with regard to skin tone but also referring to blond and red hair.
examples: She had fair hair and blue eyes.
He must be given a fair trial.

definitions.definition: Adequate , reasonable , or decent , but not excellent .
examples: Their performance has been only fair .
The patient was in a fair condition after some treatment.

subdefinitions.definition: Free from obstacles or hindrances; unobstructed; unencumbered; open; direct; said of a road, passage, etc.
examples: a fair mark;  in fair sight;  a fair view

definitions.definition: Without sudden change of direction or curvature; smooth; flowing; said of the figure of a vessel, and of surfaces, water lines, and other lines.
Taken direct from an opponent's foot, without the ball touching the ground or another player.

labels: of a ball delivered by the bowler
definitions.label_groups: cricket , of a ball delivered by the bowler

definitions.definition: Of a coin or die , having equal chance of landing on any side, unbiased .
examples: A fair coin has a 50% chance of landing on heads.

main_definition: ( original sense , archaic or literary ) Beautiful , of a pleasing appearance, with a pure and fresh quality.
secondary_definitions: Unblemished (figuratively or literally); clean and pure ; innocent.
Light in color, pale , particularly with regard to skin tone but also referring to blond and red hair.
Adequate , reasonable , or decent , but not excellent .
( nautical , of a wind ) Favorable to a ship's course.
( shipbuilding ) Without sudden change of direction or curvature; smooth; flowing; said of the figure of a vessel, and of surfaces, water lines, and other lines.
( rugby , of a catch ) Taken direct from an opponent's foot, without the ball touching the ground or another player.
( cricket , of a ball delivered by the bowler ) Not a no ball .
( statistics ) Of a coin or die , having equal chance of landing on any side, unbiased .
